Analytics and insight

This lab focuses on reasoning, not tooling. The goal is to design KPIs that people can act on without fooling themselves.

1. Types of analytics

Descriptive analytics tells you what happened. It is the starting point, not the conclusion.

2. KPI design

Good KPIs have a denominator, a decision owner, and a clear action when they move.

Your KPI contract

Missed appointment rate = Missed appointments / Total scheduled appointments. Decision owner: Operations lead. Cadence: Weekly.

Dashboard pitfalls

  • Proxy metrics

    You measure something easy, then mistake it for the outcome.

  • Vanity dashboards

    Pretty charts with no decision owner and no action.

  • No denominator

    Counts without context hide the real rate.

  • Moving definitions

    If KPI definitions change silently, trend lines become fiction.

Misleading metrics checklist

  • Is the denominator clear?
  • Can the KPI be gamed?
  • Is it stable over time, or does it change meaning?
  • Do we have confidence intervals or at least sample sizes?
  • Is there a named decision owner?
